Name: Standing Statue of a Boy with a Side Lock of Hair
Description: This sculpture depicts a boy standing on an unmarked rectangular base, in the traditional pose with the left leg forward. He is portrayed as being young with a braid of hair on one side emerging from his cap. The side lock was used by the Ancient Egyptians to indicate youth. The boy's hands are by his sides and he is wearing the short royal kilt. On the lower parts of his legs there are some traces of restoration work and part of his left arm is broken.
